Nodepool is the Zuul subsystem responsible for lifecycle management of build nodes and similar ephemeral resources. Ack. Actually it looks like we are using the link-selection sub-option for this. Because the relay IP in the tenant network is not routable for the DHCP server, the "giaddr" value is set to the IP in the management network, while the link-selection sub-option is set to the relay address in the tenant network. The server then uses the management IP of the relay agent to communicate with the agent, but the IP in the sub-option to determine the appropriate subnet for the address allocation.

The fact that there is a relay agent *per network*, with a separate IP in the management network is how traffic is isolated between tenants.

In the single-process model, with a single IP in the management network, it become necessary to use the vpn ID or circuit ID to differentiate, because address in the tenant network is not sufficient. That is, you could use the vpn ID or circuit ID to differentiate the tenant and specific tenant network.
The relay agent would set DHCP option 82 (circuit ID) based on the Neutron L2 segment.

In fact each instance of the relay needs an IP on a network that has routing to the DHCP server. This means for every namespace, we consume one IP on this management network. For this reason, the DHCP proposal [1] that Don Kehn made is preferable over this one.

[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/dhcp-cpnr-integration

The tenant has no control over the IP in the management network. The relay will pickup the DHCP request from the isolated L2 segment, then unicast via the management network, setting the circuit-id to differentiate the segments. It's up to the receiving DHCP server to properly interpret the options.

specs/xena/approved/glance/glance-unifie.message:
Is this going to be config option, which will be read from glance-api and enforced at the startup?

We also need to make sure sending sighup (reload) to glance-api reloads the new quotas or so.

So after studying about limits, i came to conclusion that if we try to set these through glance then we will not be able to set different limits for different tenants/projects. So I think we need to document this that if new tenant is added then admin needs to set limits for that project/tenant first.

Also I guess we need to make a provision to failsafe process that if limits is enabled and it is not registered yet then it should ignore the enforcement.

Is there any possibility that we can set this through glance during/at service startup phase.
The reason I am asking is;

1. this will reduce the administrator work to explicitly set these limits
2. If someone (Administrator) by mistake modified the limit then it will not take effect unless and until glance service is restarted.
3. Glance will have control over theses limits.

We can have a config option with default values which will be set during service startup so this would also skips the possibility that we have upgraded to latest version, enabled the new limits by setting config option true in the api.conf and forget to set these limits explicitly using command line or limit APIs.

No, these are set in keystone via the API (that's what unified limits are). So something like:

 openstack limit create image_size_total --project $ID 100

There's no HUP handling needed, they take effect immediately. If you look at my tempest tests, I change the quota during the test and probe that it takes effect immediately:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/788346/5/tempest/api/image/v2/test_images.py

> So after studying about limits, i came to conclusion that if we try to set these through glance then we will not be able to set different limits for different tenants/projects. So I think we need to document this that if new tenant is added then admin needs to set limits for that project/tenant first.

I'm not sure what you mean. A limit is registered in keystone with a default. That default applies to every tenant automatically unless a specific limit for that tenant is set. So, I would register the limit of image_size=1000 once, when I deploy all the services. Then, I would add (or delete) specific limits for image_size on a given tenant later. That does not need to be before the tenant starts being used, but could be.

> Also I guess we need to make a provision to failsafe process that if limits is enabled and it is not registered yet then it should ignore the enforcement.

The limits are registered once, at deployment time. If they're not registered, oslo_limit considers them to be zero, which means "no quota". The alternative would be to consider them to be "unlimited quota" but that would probably be more surprising to people. If they enable limits via keystone in glance's config, they need to have registered those limits (with defaults) in keystone first. See this note on the config knob:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance/+/788054/4/glance/common/config.py
Do we really need this? I am not able to see any benefit from it.

I think we should because the staging area is likely very small and constrained compared to the total image storage space, especially if it's local storage on the controllers. This allows an operator to prevent a user from staging 1TiB of data and never importing it. If they choose to just limit users by total image storage and not number of images, then a user could fill the staging area without consequence.

Is there some argument for *not* doing this? I've already written the code, so it's not like it's a large undertaking. Staging disk space is more constrained than regular disk space, so it seems like it would be pretty straightforward to want to limit its usage, especially since it's not really billable currently (for those that do).
I would like to see opinions of other cores for the same. My view is 50-50 about having it.

It's not really an alternative, but we could add something to this to enforce a quota per store instead of or in addition to a global one. We would do something like check the image_size_total_$store limit (although I think I need to extend oslo_limit to allow to me check to see if that is registered, else fall back to the global).

If people think that's important for the first round of this, let me know and I'll put that in here.
Also what will be the upgrade impact for this?

It's stated right here, but I'll clarify. There's no upgrade impact directly - someone can upgrade to Xena without any change. Once on Xena, if they want to enable quotas, they register them in keystone at least and then flip the config knob in Glance to start using them. No data migration required, but some users could immediately be "over quota" depending on what they have set quota values for.

But yeah, I will expand this out.

Hmm, this was brought up in the PTG, but I'm not sure it's really a problem:

 dan@guaranine:~/devstack$ openstack image show foo-snap1 -c name -c size -c properties -f yaml
 name: foo-snap1
 properties:
   base_image_ref: 3c5a7f05-0988-427a-a356-23f8584b7b28
   boot_roles: member,reader,admin
   hw_machine_type: pc
   image_location: snapshot
   image_state: available
   image_type: snapshot
   instance_uuid: b647e362-37d4-4071-8ddb-d897935bd792
   locations:
   - metadata:
       store: robust
     url: rbd://b6509810-f444-4724-a559-21b37207c260/images/8a369348-2ae4-41fd-ae14-5eeb49478e51/snap
   os_hidden: false
   owner_project_name: demo
   owner_user_name: admin
   stores: robust
   user_id: b5d4f7ae1c544265b35986af2e0547fa
 size: 1073741824

The image size is what nova considers the root disk size, so 1G here. It's technically less on the disk because of the CoW, but I think it's reasonable to tell the user it's the full size, and it matches what we'd get with a flattened file-based image anyway.
Ah, so maybe it's a cinder issue not nova? Maybe we can get Brian to comment.
I think this is about https://bugs.launchpad.net/mos/+bug/1666450
I think you also need to explain about use_keystone_limits config option and it will be by default off. You need to enable it to use the limits for glance quotas.

This maps to the current 'user_storage_quota'.  The other size-related limit we have now is 'image_size_cap' which limits the largest size image a user can have.  I wonder whether something like image_size_cap would be worth doing as part of this effort.

I don't think it fits well, because of the way oslo_limit works. We give it a limit name, a current value, and a requested value, and it tells us if we're over that limit or not. It doesn't provide a general purpose way to say "tell me what this value is for this user", although it definitely could (and will have to in order to make an API to expose the current limit along with usage).

I think that what you're describing is a bit in between a config option and the limits that keystone exposes. Maybe the original authors intended to allow aribitrary things to be set like that, but you're almost on the verge of treating keystone as a generic key=value store at that point.

I really wonder about this one.  An image is only a few DB rows + data, and the data is already covered by image_size_total.  I don't want to penalize the ArchLinux user with 10MB images vs. the Windows user with 20GB images.  An operator can simply set this to -1, but I really wonder whether it's needed at all.

I should have said: If others don't want this, then I can certainly drop those patches (although the discussion below makes it sound like at least we want the staging count). However, they're already done, so throwing that away doesn't buy us much.

Well, I was mirroring the quotas in nova (instances, a count) and neutron (subnets, networks, ports, all counts).

I agree it's the least compelling, but we've definitely had operators in nova that want the instances quota so I presume it's useful.
agree with this 100%

This makes me wonder whether we want something like the image_count_total to apply to non-deleted, non-active images, to limit the damage  someone could do by simultaneous imports of large images that are individually OK but collectively exceed the quota.

Ack, this is what I have now:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance/+/788326/1/glance/db/sqlalchemy/api.py

I guess we could separate these into image_count_total (or _active?) and image_count_staged based on your argument. I can definitely see an operator not wanting to limit your staging usage based on space, but does want you to commit to importing or not by limiting you to only two inflight importing images at a time or something. Giving you 100G of staging quota so you can import a single large image, but also letting you import 500 tiny images might defeat the utility in certain circumstances.
Relative to the time it takes for an image of real-life size to go active, however, this is pretty negligible.

You've probably already thought of this, but "the docs" include the help text for the new option that enables oslo limits, plus notes in the current quota options that will be ignored when that option is enabled.
For sure :)
This will not account Image Import process utilizing staging which is likely the largest portion of it.
Works for me!
So the problem is that all the copy jobs will use staging as well and they happen on "active" image (One of the holes I referred to).
Yep, as noted earlier, that's my plan. Shouldn't be hard.
How about if we look at 'active' images that also have the 'os_glance_importing_to_stores' image property on them?  We'd also know their size since they're already active images.
Will include importing status here and below.
In case of 'web-download' import method, 'importing' state might do that as well.

OK, so it would be 'uploading' + 'saving' + 'importing', and detect the copy-image operations by either looking at the current tasks, or by looking at 'active' images with 'os_glance_importing_to_stores' property.
Ack, yep.

This sounds little bit strange.
I think it's better to underline it as a drawback in the documentation.
Yep, agree with all the comments here that it would be awkward, I was just trying to come up with options to address concerns. Sounds like I can just remove this paragraph.

This would be really frustrating when I'm trying to upload a 10M image and I know I've got 900M left in my quota, but I get rejected anyway because this config value is set at 1G.

We just need to explain to operators that the image_count_uploading is a kind of proxy for the amount of stage that can be consumed, but it's an inexact proxy.  The alternative would be to only allow import methods that know the size of the data before it hits the stage, which I guess would be copy-image and web-download (though I don't think they do this currently).  Or as you mentioned somewhere, we could modify upload/stage to require the user to specify how big the file is in advance.
I'm OK with dropping this paragraph; you may want to add a note to the doc impact section about "need to explain the soft limit and what knobs are available to control filling up the stage".

I'm referring to the situation where we've been told what the image size is at upload time.

But I agree that because glance allows uploading an image of unknown size, we're really in a tough spot to provide a hard quota limit, so a soft limit is the obvious first improvement we can make.
Not only that, but the image_size is read-only property so we will never get the size beforehand.

Could we rather just use the information if the said limits has been set in Keystone as condition? While I'm normally ok with having new features behind config option this kind of sounds like one of those cases where we just bloat the config file.

As in if the limits have not been set, we do operate like always before, but if they have been initialized, we enforce them.
Ooof ... gr8 yeah then this unfortunately makes sense. And it's not the single boolean in our config object but the dozen lines extra fluff into the config file to make that single boolean happening.

We don't really get to know this directly. Unified limits aren't supposed to be optional, and as such, oslo-limit hides a missing limit as "no quota" from us to prevent forgetting to set a limit and having a runaway usage type issue.

We could extend oslo-limit to expose this, or probe keystone itself for that information, but all of that seems a little overkill to avoid a single boolean config toggle. The latter also avoids us constantly asking keystone whether a limit is set in the case where an operator doesn't want to have quotas enabled.
++ thanks for capturing this issue here!

Sure, but FWIW, I couldn't reproduce it myself and I asked Rajat if he knew anything about cinder problems related to this and he didn't.

So, if you have more information, it'd be good to expose that so I can document it here and account for it.
+1 for this
I guess importing_to_store is missing from here, but can be added if new spin is required.

I'm counting the actual importing operation as part of the upload here, so I'm expecting an in-progress import to count against your staging/uploading quota until it's done. But yep, if I respin I will make that clear.

The service names and service types are flipped here.
Line 3212 should say "heat", and this description can be simplified:

"Orchestration service capabilities are appear in an add-on guidance."

There are three "platforms" that this guideline can satisfy: "OpenStack Powered Platform", "OpenStack Powered Compute", "OpenStack Powered Storage". The add-ons bring in their own "required"/designated sections. So saying that they are "not considered required" may be confusing - they are by definition "add-ons" 😊 and these "add-ons" extend "os_powered_compute" which figures in the "OpenStack Powered Platform" and "OpenStack Powered Compute" platforms.

heat


The schema suggests this has to be a project name, not service type, see line 3206, 3153, 3016 and so on..

Spelling..

Instead of saying "Heat is not considered required ... "; Isn't it more correct to say: 

"Orchestration service capabilities appear in an add-on guidance."

because if you want the OpenStack Powered with Orchestration validation, heat will be "required"; and because heat also has many "sections", some of which are considered designated, and some not..

The phase for deploying network policy is deliver-network-policy and is defined in /manifest/type/multi-tenant/phases. This can be tested by pointing the airship configuration to point to reference-multi-tenant site and using the command airshipctl phase run deliver-network-policy.
Host names are already available at  manifests/function/hostendpoint-generator/replacements/host-endpoints.yaml.
I seem to have got wrong path above. Correct path is manifests/site/reference-airship-core/host-inventory/hostgenerator/host-generation.yaml

manifests/type/multi-tenant/target/workl.message: Are we using this file anywhere else or can we delete it?
Yes, this is not needed and needs to be removed.
I'd not mix host endpoints with network policies. Can you separate them?
Host endpoints belong to site manifests.

Good catch.  The HostEndpoints will be per-baremetal-host, not per-subcluster-host, right?  If so, we could create a Template function in treasuremap to generate them from the hosts catalogue, very similar to how the the BareMetalHost objects are generated by this function in airshipctl:  https://github.com/airshipit/airshipctl/tree/master/manifests/function/hostgenerator-m3

Thanks, Matt. If hostendpoints needed for all baremetal hosts or not depend on the interface used to create HEP. With respect to subclusters, HEPs are only needed on worker nodes with interface 'vm-infra-bridge', while the target cluster needs HEPs for all the nodes with interface 'OAM'.

It is debatable if to have HEPs with 'vm-infra-bridge' for master nodes. They too got "vm-infra-bridge' but seems no purpose.

So the template function that generates HEPs may have to take this into account. We can keep it simple for now by just creating two HEPs per node, one each for OAM and vm-infra-bridge.
Note: if the only thing that's site-specific is the hostname, then we might not need any new files at site level for this-- the hostname is in the host catalogue already.

tools/check_irc_access.py.message:
Previously msg was defined as:

  msg = e.arguments[0][1:]

I don't expect the format of the messages changes between freenode and oftc. Do we need to take the later slice here? Or do we want to include the auth info in the msg?

The format of the messages changes between freenode and oftc. On Freenode we rely on the identify-msg capability which prefixes identified nicks with a "+", and the [1:] was subsequently stripping that from each nick prior to comparison. That is not consistent behavior across networks.

doc/source/releasenotes/r5_release.rst.message: Deleted - this feature is removed from R5
Added support for orchestrating updates to the Intel N3000 FPGA Programmable Acceleration Card across the subclouds in a distributed cloud configuration.
Will be in Distributed Cloud guide, but is not merged yet.

In Distributed Cloud configurations, 'admin' endpoints for the platform keystone services (e.g. Configuration API, DcManager API, etc. ) on systemController and subclouds are HTTPS with internally generated certificates.  This feature adds support for automatically renewing the certificates associated with these 'admin' endpoints.
Will be in Security guide ... but review is not yet merged.

Starlingx now integrates the open source Vault secret management into the StarlingX solution. The StarlingX integration of Vault uses open source Raft (PVC-based) as its storage backend. For more information, see, https://www.vaultproject.io/. 

The following services are supported:
• Encryption-as-a-service / Secret Management: Vault provides data encryption for applications and is used to store and access secrets.
• Vault-manager: The Vault-manager pod handles the initialization of Vault, configuring Transport Layer Security (TLS) for all Vault communication that provides the ability to automatically unseal Vault pods in deployments where an external autounseal provider is not available.

Cloud Platform supports image security policies using the Portieris
admission controller. Portieris uses a Kubernetes Mutating Admission Webhook to modify Kubernetes resources such as pods, deployments, and others, at the point of creation, to ensure that Kubernetes runs only policy compliant images; for example, only signed images. The Cloud Platform integration of Portieris is integrated with cert-manager and works with external registries, with an associated Notary server for holding images’ trust data.
Done but replaced Cloud Platform with StarlingX (2 instances)

this is a prep only feature ... talked to ghada ... we should remove it from the StarlingX R5 release notes ... and save its general introduction for StarlignX R6 ... since we don't have any actual documentation on how to use the prep stuff yet.

A new personality of node 'EdgeWorker' is now available. It provides an agile approach to take existing hosts which are running different kinds of OS into StarlingX management. A typical usecase is to configure OS pre-installed industrial PCs as EdgeWorker nodes.

StarlingX has updated its SNMP solution to be a containerized SNMP solution, delivered as an optional system application.  Net-SNMP is still used as the underlying SNMP Agent.  SNMP is configured through helm-overrides of the SNMP system application.  And the SNMP system application now supports both SNMPv2c and SNMPv3.
Remove 1000 subclouds from the title. We don't support 1000 subclouds in stx.5.0.
The distributed cloud deployment now supports up to 200 AIO-SX subclouds.
Will be in Distributed Cloud guide, but is not merged yet.
Please remove this. This is really only applies to "FPGA image update orchestration for distributed cloud" which is covered above.
Please add SDO before device, as this is a short description and we want to make it explicit that the device is SDO based.(device come with SDO agent)

Add link to Node management guide: Configuring VF Interfaces rate limiting Using the CLI, 
and Planning guide: Kubernetes Verified Commercial Hardware.
Please add SDO before device as this is short version and we want to make sure that the device is SDO(that is device comes with SDO agent)

Hi Mary, please update the description here to align with the updated edge worker doc.

Edgeworker is a new personality of nodes. Edgeworker nodes are typically small systems running dedicated workloads with Ubuntu as its operating system. They usually do not meet worker nodes' minimum requirements but now they can be managed by StarlingX.
This is probably the best place to add it.

modules/puppet-patching/src/patching/man.message:
I think what you actually want to do here is something like this:
https://opendev.org/starlingx/stx-puppet/src/commit/b46ce5704f2b23864ea8fb1d379a53fffd656e00/modules/puppet-sysinv/src/sysinv/manifests/agent.pp#L27

so:

Patching_config<||> ~> Service['sw-patch-agent.service']
if $::personality == 'controller' {
  Patching_config<||> ~> Service['w-patch-controller-daemon.service']
}

This "Patching_config<||> ~>" should maybe be in the init.pp, as well - or maybe that's the only place it would need to be. ie. changing this:
https://opendev.org/starlingx/stx-puppet/src/commit/b46ce5704f2b23864ea8fb1d379a53fffd656e00/modules/puppet-patching/src/patching/manifests/init.pp#L31-L43

to:

  Patching_config<||> ~> service { 'sw-patch-agent.service':
    ensure    => 'running',
    enable    => true,
    subscribe => File[$::patching::params::patching_conf],
  }
  if $::personality == 'controller' {
    Patching_config<||> ~> service { 'sw-patch-controller-daemon.service':
      ensure    => 'running',
      enable    => true,
      subscribe => Service['sw-patch-agent.service'],
    }
  }

Thanks Don. The Patching_config<||> collector and verifed it works for my issue. I think we no longer need to add the subsription to the config file in the sw-patch-agent.service after chaining the patching_config, do we? And the sw-patch-controller-daemon.service can leave as-is.

To try this out, I made the change to init.pp only on my system. Then I edited patching.conf to change the keystone_authtoken/password value, and did a lock/unlock of the controller. When the controller came back up, I verified:
1. password in patching.conf is updated, checked the timestamp of the file
2. checked in patching.log and saw patch-controller launched before the patching.conf was updated, then re-launched after
3. checked the corresponding puppet.log and saw the services restarted as a result of the Patching_config change

I then did another lock/unlock of the controller and verified the patching.conf was unmodified (since the content was already correct) and the patching daemon was not restarted.

Please use this method, updating init.pp with "Patching_config<||> ~> service" as above, and verify it resolves your issue.
Please add the "Patching_config<||> " here, and you can likely drop the subscribe here as well.

templates/virtual-baremetal-servers.yaml.message:
We have to use a different parameter name here.

When you set "config_drive: true" in the environment to use it for BMC and undercloud nodes, this would also enable it here. If I am not mistaken, this will cause the instances to have 2 disks, a very small vda with the config-drive and the bigger disk based on the flavor as vdb.

When later using ironic to deploy to the virtual baremetal nodes ironic can end up trying to write the image to the wrong disk, and fail due to size.

If you use root_device hints to control wich disk ironic uses, there is also the issue that cloud-init on the ironic provisioned node will see the host clouds metadata, and not the cloud init data ironic put's on a partition.

I'm sure TripleO CI will break ...


I think a different name such as 'virtual_baremetal_config_drive' should be used here, preferably with a description highlighting the potential pit-fall with ironic. For "extra" node where a generic cloud image is used we can then set 'virtual_baremetal_config_drive: true' in addition to 'config_drive: true'

sushy/resources/eventservice/eventdestin.message: I guess the headers should be NULL on a GET?  Could you add a comment as to why they are deleted?

Sure! I will add a note on why I'm removing from the payload =)
should this be named EventDestination as it's in Redfish schema?

I've noticed this too, as long as there is EventService.subscriptions and not EventService.event_destinations it should be fine. The question is are we overriding types named by Redfish? Ofc, not clear to me why it's named that way in Redfish spec, maybe there is some history.
Yeah, I will change to EventDestination

tbh I'm in doubt on how we should handle this, the schema is called EventDestination,
but the urls are /redfish/v1/EventService/Subscriptions/<Id>, 
In the EventService schema they have
  "Subscriptions": {
    "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/EventService/Subscriptions"
  }
I'm open to change EventDestination, let's see what other's will think
They will always be empty on GET, since they are always used for the POST they will be in the payload and we will filter to pass the headers in the request to create a subscription.
The create itself is handle in the collections part (I was looking at how we handle Volume for example, so I think it should be fine to not have here)
it still could be useful if this class were used in create method.

is that's how it is specified in Redfish or implemented?

The spec has:

"This property shall contain an object consisting of the names and values of of HTTP header to be included with every event POST to the Event Destination.  This property shall be null on a GET."

The way I see this is that they are still part of payload, but once set can't get its value back (probably because of security as it can contain auth details).

Is it somewhere specified that HttpHeaders need to be taken out from payload and passed separately like in ln116?
humm that's weird, before testing in iDRAC I had to enable the event service (it was disabled by default)

From IRC

> <mraineri>	ajya: The HttpHeaders property in the POST request will contain any headers the client would like to be provided when receiving event notifications
> <mraineri>	The reason it's an empty array in GET responses is one of the use cases is the client might be specifying authentication parameters for the event listenter
> <mraineri>	So, it's an attempt to avoid information leakage

This transformation is not necessary. Why HttpHeaders in Body do not work on tested BMCs, is another question. I will check on iDRAC.
For now or later I see that HttpHeaders could be added to property list like any other in EventDestination class given that there are BMCs that work with it.

I did some tests in iDRAC and iLO, if we keep the headers in the payload the subscription is not created, to me it makes sense that the headers from the payload will turn in the headers for the request to create a subscription
iDRAC gives 400 Bad request when passing non-empty HttpHeader, that's strange, need to clarify this. The pattern is not something I have seen before in Redfish.

it worked for me without HttpHeader in body or setting [], but this could be something to do with iDRAC.

Will ping Mike in IRC about generic Redfish approach re this.

doc/source/reference/job_def.rst.message:
I think order of the semaphores in the job configs matters too in order to reduce contention. You want all jobs to use a consistent ordering of semaphores so that they aren't acquired in different orders by different jobs causing multiple jobs to all get their first semaphore but then fail to get the second because the second is the first semaphore for some other job.

We can document that as something users need to be mindful of in their configs or we could apply a sort order internally.
I'm going to go with sorting and not mention it in the docs since it shouldn't matter to users.
That's a good point, and I honestly don't know which approach is best.  Maybe sorting?

neutron/tests/unit/db/test_db_base_plugi.message:
I think that what you want to test is the following execution flow:
- coro: read query
- main thread: read and delete
- coro: delete query

Because you are creating green threads, the coroutine will be executed once the main thread deletion is done. In order to simulate this, you'll need to:
- Add a sleep, in the coro, between the read and the deletion.
- Before starting the context in the main thread, start executing the coro (using sleep to pass the GIL).
- Wait for the coro, to finish the coro execution.
--> that should throw a StaleDataError

You also have another problem: the context is the same in both threads. If you close the session in one of them, the session of this context in the other one will be closed too (new engine facade, no nested transactions). You need to create two contexts.

> I think that what you want to test is the following execution flow:

neutron_lib/db/model_query.py.message:
When this query makes sense? In other words: if we retrieve the whole model ("port", for example), we'll also retrieve all backrefs related to "port" ("network", "standartattrs", etc). In this case, why do we need to add an extra field that is not related to "port"?

In the other case, when we defined a "field" parameter, the query will be restricted to this single column. Does it make sense then?

nit: 

    lazy_fields = lazy_fields or []
    ...
    for field in lazy_fields:
        query = query.options(lazyload(field))

How are we going to override the default load mode? Now we can (1) load the default OVO, using the DB references or (2) load a single DB register column. IMO, to accept this patch we need a new loading strategy that will allow this kind of queries.

This change is not quite related to OVO and works at a lower when full model is queried (not a single field). We  can override the default load mode according to [1]: "Lazy loading can be enabled for a given attribute that is normally configured in some other way using the lazyload() loader option" - which is also confirmed with tests that I performed.

For example of usage please check https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/790691

[1] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/loading_relationships.html#lazy-loading
looks nicer indeed, will update if have to re-spin, thanks

Right, but the example you provided in [1] does nothing to the SQL query. The fields to added to be lazyloaded in [2] are not in the port query because those three child registers are loaded as subqueries [3][4][5].

I tested with a parameter that is loaded using a join [6]: port.qos_policy_binding. I've tested that the query removes this parameter from the output and from the SQL query:
- With qos_policy_binding: http://paste.openstack.org/show/805708/
- Lazyloading qos_policy_binding: http://paste.openstack.org/show/805709/

So yes, this patch makes sense to "peel off", from some specific SQL queries, some unneeded fields that are not going to be read in the retrieved DB object. That could reduce the complexity and thus the query time.

Of course, this new feature must be use with care: those fields that are not in the main SQL query will be retrieved, when read from the DB resultant object, using secondary queries. That could increase the DB access time.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/790691
[2]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/790691/2/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py#1527
[3]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/dd24662e5316a72fc5b9cbfe36bec1705ce2c505/neutron/plugins/ml2/models.py#L92
[4]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/dd24662e5316a72fc5b9cbfe36bec1705ce2c505/neutron/plugins/ml2/models.py#L132
[5]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/dd24662e5316a72fc5b9cbfe36bec1705ce2c505/neutron/db/models/port_forwarding.py#L60
[6]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/dd24662e5316a72fc5b9cbfe36bec1705ce2c505/neutron/db/qos/models.py#L123

> When this query makes sense? In other words: if we retrieve the whole model ("port", for example), we'll also retrieve all backrefs related to "port" ("network", "standartattrs", etc). In this case, why do we need to add an extra field that is not related to "port"?
> 

The idea is to override default load mode, so we don't retrieve all backrefs related to port, instead we set 'lazy' mode for those which we don't need in current case. I'll upload a patch to neutron soon.

> In the other case, when we defined a "field" parameter, the query will be restricted to this single column. Does it make sense then?

Not quite, this case is when we need most of the fields.
Thank for analysis Rodolfo! Indeed there must be perf testing done before any new lazy_fields are added to a query

cinder/volume/api.py.message: I wonder if its more proper to add status_check after line 500. conditional_update only returns 0/1 but we can still get the Volume-info from volume object.
Doing so risks race conditions that will return incorrect/misleading info, which is not a benefit over how this works now.

The problem there is that the contents we have in memory could not be up to date, so if we use it to report the error we may be reporting an incorrect cause of failure.

And if you reload the data to get the most up to date data it may have changed since the conditional update failed, and we  may find that according to the latest state the operation would succeed, so we cannot know why the update failed.  And now that we know that it would succeed we would want to retry the operation, but what if it failed again?

Unfortunately all the solutions I can think of have downsides (including increased code complexity, additional DB requests, etc.).

Indeed. This patch address the root-cause instead of just bumping up the limit and crossing fingers. 2GiB limit isn't likely to break anything though.
We saw a few problems where we had to increase to 2GiB so I think we should keep this.

It's glibc/malloc doing this - https://sourceware.org/glibc/wiki/MallocInternals#Arenas_and_Heaps

qemu-img is oblivous to all of this. If it mallocs 64k it just gets an address from glibc malloc. Malloc will take from one of it's pre-allocated address ranges. 

No memory will be used unless/until qemu-img writes data to the addresses, so ultimately qemu-img is behaving precisely the same and has the same memory footprint - it's just these pre-allocated arenas from glibc that are changing.
1 might be better actually. It would then be deterministic. It seems to have no effect on performance in my completely non-scientific test converting a ~1gb qcow2.
Based on the NOTE 1-3 would have same footprint, but 3 would provide better performance.

> Based on the NOTE 1-3 would have same footprint, but 3 would provide better performance.

Then the note isn't clear :-) More malloc arenas will mean more address space used:

For a 1.1gb (4gb virt) overcloud-full.qcow2:
  MALLOC_ARENA_MAX=3:
    peak address space usage =~ 325mb
    peak memory usage (max RSS) = 28396kb
    elapsed time 6.69s
  MALLOC_ARENA_MAX=1:
    peak address space usage =~ 181mb
    peak memory usage (max RSS) = 27116kb
    elapsed time 6.54s

> 1 might be better actually. It would then be deterministic.
I'm wrong it wouldn't be deterministic. Would also need to run qemu-img convert with single thread (-m 1).

Re performance - the number of malloc arenas and the number of threads doesn't seem to make much difference at all in the test I've run. I expect qcow2 -> raw is a very easy conversion and I/O is the limiting factor.

releasenotes/notes/add_qos_pps_rule_api_.message: CRUD is a commonly used abbrev (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Create,_read,_update_and_delete)

I'm not sure if there is a fixed order of this abbreviation for 'Create, Update, Retrieve and Delete'. The style of 'CURD' is just my personal habit. Maybe for English native speaker, the "CRUD" may have a smooth pronunciation. But IMO, it should not be read as a word. This combination 'CURD' or 'CRUD' can only be read by letters one by one to avoid unnecessary ambiguity or misunderstand especially for non native English speakers.
